unique_users: International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer, 16 September

selected_quotes: So what did the Montreal Protocol do for us?? Quite a lot actually!
Without Montreal protocol, ozone hole would have been 40% larger, UV levels 8-12% higher paper
This is quite interesting. Paper suggesting what would have happened to the ozone hole without the Montreal Protocol
Ozonloch: ohne Montreal-Abkommen wäre es schlimm geworden. Mit hoher UV-Strahlung auch bei uns

citation.abstract: Chlorine- and bromine-containing ozone-depleting substances (ODSs) are controlled by the 1987 Montreal Protocol. In consequence, atmospheric equivalent chlorine peaked in 1993 and has been declining slowly since then. Consistent with this, models project a gradual increase in stratospheric ozone with the Antarctic ozone hole expected to disappear by ∼2050. However, we show that by 2013 the Montreal Protocol had already achieved significant benefits for the ozone layer. Using a 3D atmospheric chemistry transport model, we demonstrate that much larger ozone depletion than observed has been avoided by the protocol, with beneficial impacts on surface ultraviolet. A deep Arctic ozone hole, with column values <120 DU, would have occurred given meteorological conditions in 2011. The Antarctic ozone hole would have grown in size by 40% by 2013, with enhanced loss at subpolar latitudes. The decline over northern hemisphere middle latitudes would have continued, more than doubling to ∼15% by 2013.
citation.title: Quantifying the ozone and ultraviolet benefits already achieved by the Montreal Protocol

news.title: Ozone treaty 'prevented skin cancer deaths'
news.summary: MONTREAL BENEFITS: The ozone hole over the Antarctic would have been 40 per cent bigger in 2013 if the Montreal Protocol hadn't curbed the production of CFCs, according to a new study.
